results.headline: In a World of Extremists, Shades of Gray Add Ambiguity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Traitor

results.summary_short: “Traitor,” a somber, absorbing and only moderately preposterous new thriller written and directed by Jeffrey Nachmanoff, manages an impressive feat of economy.

results.headline: The Rest Was Silence, but Then Came the Sequel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hamlet 2

results.summary_short: “Hamlet 2” belongs to the school of free-for-all satiric farce whose creators ball up wads of ideas, apply chewing gum and hurl them against the wall to see what sticks.

results.headline: Surviving Katrina With a Big Personality and a Video Camera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trouble the Water

results.summary_short: Kimberly Roberts, the dynamo at the center of the documentary “Trouble the Water,” didn’t wait out the storm from her home in the Lower Ninth Ward; she chased it.

results.headline: Heavy Automotive Metal in a Rusty Pileup Soufflé

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death Race

results.summary_short: “Death Race” is a supercharged junkyard apocalypse powered by an unabashed relish for brutal comeuppance and a flair for delirious vehicular mayhem.

results.headline: Back to the Womb to Discover Spirits of an Older, Nobler Age

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Momma's Man

results.summary_short: “Momma’s Man” is a touchingly true film, part weepie, part comedy, about the agonies of navigating that slippery slope called adulthood.

results.headline: Tackling Our Unsexy National Debt

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I.O.U.S.A.

results.summary_short: Patrick Creadon’s resolutely nonpartisan film tracks America’s “fiscal cancer” through centuries of budgetary highs and lows.

results.headline: An Existential Mope, Hither and Thither He Goes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sensation of Sight

results.summary_short: David Strathairn suffers a midlife crisis and oppressively mannered filmmaking in this tale of small town tragedy and whimsy run amok.

results.headline: Tossing Around an Old Pigskin With a Rocker, Turned Director

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Longshots

results.summary_short: Fred Durst of Limp Bizkit fame directs what may be the most formulaic football movie ever made.

results.headline: A Muddled Walk Through a Segregationist History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dare Not Walk Alone

results.summary_short: In the civil rights documentary “Dare Not Walk Alone,” director Jeremy Dean makes a valiant attempt to juxtapose past and present, but his execution is so muddled it’s almost unwatchable.

results.headline: The Misadventures of an Ex-Centerfold

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The House Bunny

results.summary_short: Anna Faris proves herself a faux-bimbo par excellence in this breezy, ditzy comedy about a Playboy bunny who goes back to school.

results.headline: Watching as Richard Serra Thinks Big and Does Big
results.display_title: Richard Serra: Thinking On Your Feet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Richard Serra: Thinking On Your Feet

results.summary_short: Operating at the intersection of art and industrial engineering, Richard Serra is an informative if unanimated guide through “Thinking on Your Feet.”

results.headline: Middle-Aged Heavy Metal Drummer Meets Under-Age Band

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rocker

results.summary_short: Watching Rainn Wilson gyrate in “The Rocker,” you can’t help wondering if Mr. Wilson is inhabiting a role that was originally turned down by Jack Black.

results.headline: Evil Reflected

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mirrors

results.summary_short: A possessed nun, an alcoholic ex-cop and a mess of shattered glass drive “Mirrors,” a minor chiller and major downer from the talented Alexandre Aja.

results.headline: Love in Transition

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bachna Ae Haseeno

results.summary_short: “Bachna Ae Haseeno” grows more serious and interesting as it contemplates the various permutations of romance in a culture with rapidly changing sexual mores.

results.headline: The Portrait of Two Ladies

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vicky Cristina Barcelona

results.summary_short: “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” is a rueful comedy about two young American women who savor many Continental delicacies.

results.headline: Two Men Wage a War Only to Harm the Spoils

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Girl Cut in Two

results.summary_short: “A Girl Cut in Two” is a rich, textured divertissement from Claude Chabrol, a sinister master of the art.

results.headline: Fraught Life of a Cast-Iron Songstress
results.display_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer

results.summary_short: The portrait of Anita O’Day that emerges in this documentary is of a woman who always lived by her own rules.

results.headline: A Blue-Collar Adventurer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Brooks: Monster Slayer

results.summary_short: “Jack Brooks: Monster Slayer” harks back to the drive-in classics of yesteryear with unapologetic nostalgia and undisguised affection.

results.headline: An Actor’s Playful Tribute to a Dissident Director
results.display_title: Never Apologize: A Personal Visit with Lindsay Anderson

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Never Apologize: A Personal Visit with Lindsay Anderson

results.summary_short: Malcolm McDowell is thoroughly engaging in “Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson.”

results.headline: An Action Comedy With a Little Song and Dance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Singh is Kinng

results.summary_short: “Singh Is Kinng” isn’t a great movie. But the immensely likable Akshay Kumar shines as a Capraesque hero who spreads bedrock Indian values.
